case_name: Commissioner of Agricultural Income-tax v. Assessee

facts.text: This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Kerala in Tax Revision No. 12 of 1957

anchor.surface_text: This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Kerala in Tax Revision No. 12 of 1957.

facts.text: The respondent is the assessee who owned an estate of 590 acres in South Malabar district, number in Kerala State

anchor.surface_text: The respondent who is the assessee owned an estate of 590 acres in South Malabar district, number in Kerala State.

facts.text: Out of that area 85 acres were companyered by pepper, arecanut, paddy and companyonut cultivation

anchor.surface_text: Out of that area 85 acres were companyered by pepper, arecanut, paddy and companyonut cultivation while the rest, i.e., 505 acres,

facts.text: The rest, i.e., 505 acres, had rubber plantations upon it

anchor.surface_text: had rubber plantations upon it.

facts.text: 235 acres were occupied by immature number-bearing rubber trees

anchor.surface_text: Of that area 235 acres were occupied by immature number-bearing rubber trees and 270 acres had mature rubber trees.
and 270 acres had mature rubber trees.

facts.text: The assessment relates to the year 1955-56

anchor.surface_text: The assessment relates to the year 1955-56, the accounting year being the year ending March 31, 1955.

facts.text: The accounting year being the year ending March 31, 1955

anchor.surface_text: the accounting year being the year ending March 31, 1955.

facts.text: The respondent claimed from out of the income expenses relating to the maintenance and upkeep of immature number-bearing rubber trees

anchor.surface_text: The respondent claimed from out of the income expenses relating to the maintenance and upkeep of immature number-bearing rubber trees.

facts.text: The Agricultural Income-tax Tribunal held that the expenses incurred on the whole area under rubber plantations were deductible expenses and remanded the case for ascertaining the expenses incurred in forking and manuring of the number-bearing and immature rubber grown areas also

anchor.surface_text: The Agricultural Income-tax Tribunal held that the expenses incurred on the whole area under rubber plantations were deductible expenses and remanded the case for ascertaining the expenses incurred in forking and manuring of the number-bearing and immature rubber grown areas also.

facts.text: The appellant preferred a revision application to the High Court under section 54 1 of the Madras Plantations Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1955 Mad. V of 1955

anchor.surface_text: The appellant then preferred a revision application to the High Court under section 54 1  of the Madras Plantations Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1955  Mad. V of 1955 .

facts.text: The High Court held that the amount spent on the upkeep and maintenance of immature rubber trees was a deductible expenditure under s. 5 e of that Act

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the amount spent on the upkeep and maintenance of immature rubber trees was a deductible expenditure under s. 5 e  of that Act which provides Computation of agricultural income.

facts.text: The provisions of section 5 e of the Madras Act, applicable to the present case, are the same as those of section 5 j of the Travancore Cochin Agricultural Income-tax Act XXII of 1950

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of section 5  e  of the Madras Act, applicable to the present case, are the same as those of section 5  j  of the Travancore Cochin Agricultural Income-tax Act  XXII of 1950 .

facts.text: The only difference is in the last few words: in place of fir the purpose of the plantation in the former, the words for the purpose of deriving the agricultural income are used in the latter

anchor.surface_text: The only difference is in the last few words. In place of fir the purpose of the plantation in the former, the words for the purpose of deriving the agricultural income are used in the latter.

facts.text: The words of the former Act are more favourable to the respondent

anchor.surface_text: If anything, the words of the former Act are more favourable to the respondent.

facts.text: In Civil Appeals Nos. 290-292 of 1959, which was an assessment under the Travancore-Cochin Act, the court decided the question of deductibility of sums expended for purposes of forking, manuring, etc., of immature rubber trees

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeals Nos. 290-292 of 1959, which was an assessment under the Travancore-Cochin Act, we have decided the question of deductibility of sums expended for purposes of forking, manuring, etc., of immature rubber trees.

facts.text: That judgment will govern this case also

anchor.surface_text: That judgment will govern this case also.
This is an appeal by special leave against the judgment and order of the High Court of Kerala in Tax Revision No. 12 of 1957.
The appellant then preferred a revision application to the High Court under section 54 1  of the Madras Plantations Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1955  Mad. V of 1955 .

anchor.surface_text: In Civil Appeals Nos. 290-292 of 1959, which was an assessment under the Travancore-Cochin Act, we have decided the question of deductibility of sums expended for purposes of forking, manuring, etc., of immature rubber trees. That judgment will govern this case also.

concepts.interpretation: Judgment deciding deductibility under Travancore-Cochin Act governs present case under Madras Act

concepts.unlisted_description: Binding nature of prior judgment of the Court in Civil Appeals Nos. 290-292 of 1959

issues.text: Whether the amount spent on the upkeep and maintenance of immature rubber trees (including forking, manuring, etc.) is a deductible expenditure under section 5(e) of the Madras Plantations Agricultural Income Tax Act, 1955

anchor.surface_text: The High Court held that the amount spent on the upkeep and maintenance of immature rubber trees was a deductible expenditure under s. 5 e  of that Act which provides Computation of agricultural income. - The agricultural income of a person shall be companyputed after making the following deductions, namely  e  any expenditure incurred in the previous year  number being in the nature of capital expenditure or personal expenses of the assessee  laid out or expended wholly and exclusively for the purpose of the plantation. The provisions of section 5  e  of the Madras Act, applicable to the present case, are the same as those of section 5  j  of the Travancore Cochin Agricultural Income-tax Act  XXII of 1950 . The only difference is in the last few words. In place of fir the purpose of the plantation in the former, the words for the purpose of deriving the agricultural income are used in the latter. If anything, the words of the former Act are more favourable to the respondent. In Civil Appeals Nos. 290-292 of 1959, which was an assessment under the Travancore-Cochin Act, we have decided the question of deductibility of sums expended for purposes of forking, manuring, etc., of immature rubber trees.

holdings.text: The provisions of section 5(e) of the Madras Act, applicable to the present case, are the same as those of section 5(j) of the Travancore Cochin Agricultural Income-tax Act XXII of 1950, the only difference being in the last few words with the Madras Act being more favourable to the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: The provisions of section 5  e  of the Madras Act, applicable to the present case, are the same as those of section 5  j  of the Travancore Cochin Agricultural Income-tax Act  XXII of 1950 . The only difference is in the last few words. In place of fir the purpose of the plantation in the former, the words for the purpose of deriving the agricultural income are used in the latter. If anything, the words of the former Act are more favourable to the respondent.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Direct comparison of the textual wording of the two statutory provisions reveals they are the same except for minor variation more favourable to assessee.

holdings.text: The judgment in Civil Appeals Nos. 290-292 of 1959 deciding deductibility of expenditure on immature rubber trees under the Travancore-Cochin Act governs this case under the Madras Act.
